awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Elucidating the material properties of complex tunable biopolymer networks using single-molecule nano stress-strain transducers and sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1255446  	         PI:  Anderson, Rae	 ORG: University of San Diego

Title:  CAREER: Elucidating the material properties of complex tunable biopolymer networks using single-molecule nano stress-strain transducers and sensors

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:  Actin is a highly multifunctional protein that polymerizes and forms a wide range of complex networks with the help of numerous actin-binding proteins (ABPs).  These networks, each designed for specific biological functions, have very different structural and dynamical properties as well as mechanical responses to stress and strain.  The hierarchical nature and tunability of actin networks provides a promising route for the bottom-up design of multifunctional biomimetic materials.  However, to implement such design, the molecular dynamics and interactions that give rise to such attractive material properties must be understood.  Bulk studies have examined the viscoelasticity and mechanical response of actin networks, but such studies are unable to reveal the molecular mechanics underlying the material properties or any spatial or temporal variations within the material.  While single-molecule studies have examined the mechanical properties of single actin filaments and actin-ABP constructs, a connection between the mechanics of single network components and the bulk mechanical response is still lacking.  Using fluorescence force-measuring dual optical tweezers and a novel technique in which single molecules serve as nano stress-strain transducers and sensors, the PI will, for the first time, directly measure the resistive force exerted by a network at the molecular level (piconewton precision) in response to a molecular-scale strain (nanometer/millisecond precision) while simultaneously imaging and tracking single molecules experiencing the strain in real-time.  These measurements -- the first of their kind -- will reveal the much-needed link between molecular deformation (strain) and resistive force (stress), and will provide a powerful description of the connection between the mechanics of the individual network components and the bulk mechanical response.  Thus, results will fill a long-standing gap in knowledge regarding the mechanical behavior of complex biopolymer networks.

BROADER IMPACTS:  The project will provide critical insights to a range of fields from molecular and cellular biology to materials science and engineering.  If understood at the molecular level, the broad range of mechanical properties exhibited in biopolymer networks could be harnessed to spatiotemporally regulate the mechanical properties of novel hierarchical network-based materials.  The innovative techniques developed and employed are also highly versatile and can be used to probe a wide range of mechanical properties existing in a variety of different biomaterials.  Undergraduates from all STEM disciplines have and will continue to play a central role in the PI's research.  The PI will also continue to mentor local high school students, creating a rich interdisciplinary research experience for all students.  To further broaden the impact of the PI's research, she will develop a highly interdisciplinary Biophysics Major program at the University of San Diego that will prepare undergraduates to contribute effectively to the interdisciplinary scientific arena and attract more women to the physical sciences.  The PI will develop and teach three new courses for the major.  The PI's research and instrumentation will play an integral role in each course.  The PI, along with a diverse group of STEM faculty, is also developing a novel interdisciplinary service-learning course in which undergraduates develop interactive science projects that they execute with K-6 students in an afterschool program serving mainly first-generation immigrants.  The PI will develop a summer program in which Biophysics majors who complete this course refine and disseminate these projects to other afterschool programs and institutions.  Research results, pedagogical findings, and outreach models will be disseminated primarily via publication in peer-reviewed journals, presentations by the PI and students at professional conferences, and through robust web-based methods.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER award aimed to establish the PI's long-term goals of (1) developing an interdisciplinary research program to elucidate the complex material properties of biopolymer networks and (2) training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientific researchers and educators and informed conscientious citizens.

The overarching research outcome of the grant is the engineering of a robust experimental platform that combines optical tweezers and fluorescence microscopy to directly probe the molecular-level dynamics and intermolecular interactions occurring in novel biomaterials comprised of three ubiquitous biopolymers: actin filaments, DNA and microtubules. Using this platform, the PI and her students discovered bottom-up design principles for new multifunctional biomaterials, and mapped the material properties to the motion, forces and interactions between the biopolymers themselves.

The primary education outcome of the grant is the development and implementation of an interdisciplinary research-intensive Biophysics Major program designed to prepare undergraduates for a wide range of scientific careersand attract more women and underrepresented minorities to the physical sciences. The PI also established K-12 outreach programs and high school student research internships to broaden the reach of these efforts. 

Intellectual Merit: Networks of biopolymers - such as actin, DNA and microtubules - display complex, fascinating and useful non-Newtonian properties, especially when these biopolymers are entangled or cross-linked. As such, these networks, which biology exploits for wide-ranging cellular functions and processes,are an excellent platform for multifunctional smart materials. However, to effectively harness and specifically tune these networks, it is essential to elucidate the molecular dynamics and interactions that give rise to their attractive material properties. 

To address this need, the PI and her students engineered a suite of microscale techniques capable of applying local forces to biopolymer networks, measuring the resistive force the biopolymers exert to resist strain, and tracking the motion and deformations of individual biopolymers. This multifunctionality was achieved by combining force-measuring optical tweezers with fluorescence microscopy and computational analysis algorithms. The PI and her students used this platform to characterize the linear and nonlinear mechanical properties of first-of-their-kind mixtures of actin, DNA and microtubules with and without crosslinkers. These composite networks were custom-designed to discover the roles that polymer flexibility and size, as well as polymer-polymer interactions, play in the microscale mechanics of these novel composite materials. The results of this research revealed important design principles for creating multifunctional materials, and discovered that mixed networks displayed surprising emergent properties such as mechanical memory and extreme stiffening in response to strain - not possible in other network-based materials. These previously undiscovered properties can be exploited to create high-strength light-weight materials with mechanical properties that can be precisely tuned for applications ranging from space exploration to infrastructure to cell repair. 

As such, the results of this research provide critical insights to a range of fields from molecular and cellular biology to materials science and engineering. Further broadening the impact of the work, the new instrumentation and techniques are highly versatile and can be applied to a wide range of soft materials and complex fluids to elucidate their mechanical and structural properties with exceptional precision and detail.  

 Broader Impacts: Interdisciplinary research is widely recognized as a crucial frontier for scientific advances in the 21st century. Yet, STEM curriculum remains largely compartmentalized, hindering undergraduates' abilities to perceive the relevance of diverse science courses and use skills and knowledge from one discipline to solve problems of another. To address this need, the PI developed an interdisciplinary Biophysics Major program that prepares undergraduates to effectively contribute to the current scientific arena and attract more women to the physical sciences. The PI developed and taught three new courses for the major that showcased the PI's research and instrumentation. Further broadening the impact of the major, the PI presented the major design and outcomes at national conferences and other institutions, and served as a consultant to several physics departments at other institutions to design similar programs.

Further, undergraduate researchers played a central role in the PI's research, with 13 undergraduate co-authors contributing to 10 peer-reviewed publications. Undergraduates also presented 20 posters and talks at 6 national conferences. The two postdocs trained under this award gained valuable experience mentoring undergraduate researchers and teaching undergraduate physics and biophysics courses. Finally, the K-12 outreach programs and high school student internships that the PI developed further broadened the exposure of the future generation to science and research. 

 


Last Modified: 09/11/2019
Modified by: Rae M Robertson-Anderson
